did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
did.unittitle:
Wabash Railway Records
1836-1954

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish material from the Wabash Railway Records must be obtained from the Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Wabash Railway Records, 1836-1954, Ms2003-001, Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: The Wabash Railroad began with a 12-mile stretch of track between Meredosia and Morgan City, Illinois, which was constructed in 1838. The track was commonly known as the Northern Cross, and the Northern Cross Railroad was created from it. The company slowly expanded from the original 12-mile line, reaching the Indiana state border in 1856. During that time the railroad underwent receivership from a group of enterprising businessmen from Indiana and Ohio who wanted to create an unbroken link from Toledo, Ohio to the Mississippi River. Two railroads were formed under the same management to complete the task, eventually combining in 1856 as the Toledo, Wabash, and Western Railroad.

The company that began as the Northern Cross Railroad officially became known as the Wabash Railway in 1877, when the company reorganized itself from the Toledo, Wabash and Western Railroad due to poor economic conditions. Despite the struggling economy, the Wabash continued to push north towards Chicago. In the years that followed, the Wabash Railway was successful in running lines through Chicago, Detroit, and eventually St. Louis in time for the Louisiana Purchase Exposition in 1904.

The Wabash Railway was forced into receivership during the Depression and emerged in 1942 as the Wabash Railroad. The company continued service until it was bought by industry giant Norfolk and Western in 1964.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: The Wabash Railway Records (1836-1954) are comprised primarily of Financial Records (1895-1942) and Chairman's Files (1871-1931). Financial Records consist of documents compiled for the Interstate Commerce Commission (ICC), reports from bank affiliates, and statements of expenditures. Chairman's Files include acquisition papers, Wabash company stock, and Executive Committee meeting minutes.

In addition to Financial Records, the collection contains Wabash Historical Files (1915-1941) that include original certificates of incorporation, deeds, charts showing corporate history, and detailed maps of Wabash lines. In addition, the Oversize Materials (1836-1930) series contains a report on the history of original cost of the Wabash to 1919, which details expenses of the company at its inception. Also included in the Oversize Materials are original deeds, agreements, and statements of call loans and collateral.

The collection also documents the Wabash Railway's strategic acquisitions of railroads in order to expand its Midwestern territory to the north and east. These papers include files from railways associated with the Wabash, Grand Trunk Railway in Canada, the Pittsburgh and West Virginia Railway, as well as articles of consolidations and mortgages.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Some files have been rearranged to facilitate description of the collection, but the majority remain in their original order.

scopecontent.p: Collection of financial reports of the Wabash Railway. Reports are comprised by the auditor and divided by month.
